Mixed-metal oxide (MMO) CuMn2O4 nanoframework with a mesoporous structure was synthesized. The advantages of this mesoporous MMO are its large specific surface area, uniform pore size, and various metal valence states. MMO CuMn2O4 nanoframework showed efficient catalytic activity in the oxidative coupling of 2-amino/hydroxy/mercaptoanilines with various alcohols in the preparation of benzimidazoles, benzoxazoles, and benzothiazoles using water as the sole solvent in high yields. The efficient catalytic activity is mainly attributed to large specific surface area, increased number of active sites, solvent reorganization between the pores of mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework, and the various electronic states of the copper and manganese ions (Cu+, Cu2+, Mn3+, Mn4+) due to the Jahn-Teller effect. This research provides new insights into improving the catalytic performance of catalyst for the synthesis of nitrogen-containing five-membered ring compounds. Graphical abstract An efficient catalyst mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework is prepared for the synthesis of benzimidazole derivatives through air oxidative coupling in water. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework Oxidative coupling Solvent reorganization Jahn-teller effect Benzimidazole derivatives Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The nitrogen heterocyclic skeleton has been reported to be a key structural unit in medicinal chemistry, particularly for benzimidazole, benzoxazole, and benzothiazole, which have important applications in pharmacology as anticancer agents, proton pump inhibitors, and painkillers [1–5]. To date, various synthetic routes have been developed to prepare these molecules, including the direct condensation reaction of o-aminothiophenol with nitrile and intramolecular cyclization of 2-halogenated anilines catalyzed by metal or metal oxide [6–11]. However, many of the reported synthetic routes are accompanied by high reaction temperatures, long reaction times, and toxic organic solvents, and the precious metal or ligand catalysts cannot be recycled [12–14]. Therefore, the development of more efficient catalysts and more environmentally friendly catalyst systems is receiving increased attention. Metal oxides have a rich and tunable electronic energy band structure and therefore have a wide range of applications in industrial catalysis [15–17]. Among them, inexpensive metals are more readily available and less expensive than precious metals, which makes them more popular [18–21]. Further studies have shown that the metal oxides in the bimetallic form are able to regulate the electron energy band structure more easily, making them suitable for use in a wider range of catalytic reactions [22–26]. Nguyen et al. described an air-stable and efficient CuFe2O4 heterogeneous catalyst for the alkylation of indoles with aliphatic alcohols [27]. Shalaka et al. recently published a meso-cellular foam (MCF) supported bimetallic catalyst that provided additional active sites and improved catalytic activity for the selective one-pot synthesis of benzimidazole [28]. In our previous work, we prepared a silica-supported CuCo2O4 catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols and a self-supported CuMn2O4 catalyst for the N-alkylation of alcohols, both of which exhibited excellent catalytic performances [29,30]. Due to the charge neutrality principle and the Jahn-Teller effect, metal ions with different valence states can coexist in the mixed-metal oxide [29,31–34]. However, the application of Cu-Mn mixed-metal oxide in oxidative coupling has rarely been reported. In addition to catalyst composition, catalytic efficiency and solvent are also important factors in catalysis [35,36]. Nanoparticles are difficult to uniformly disperse and tend to polymerize, which can greatly affect the catalytic activity [37,38]. In contrast, the mesoporous inverse replica materials are well crystallized, easy to handle, and uniformly dispersed [39,40]. On the other hand, as a solvent, water has cross-linking hydrogen bonds at the intersections between pores, which can facilitate catalytic reactions within the pores of mesoporous catalysts filled with aqueous solvents [41]. In addition, water is by far the most environmentally friendly solvent [42]. In this study, we prepared an efficient mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework catalyst and applied it to the synthesis of a series of heterocyclic compounds, including benzimidazoles, benzoxazoles, and benzothiazoles, using water as the sole solvent (Fig. 1 ). Various characterization approaches were used to characterize the microstructure and measure the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the catalyst. In addition, the valence states of metals (Cu+, Cu2+, Mn3+, Mn4+) in the catalyst were analyzed. After optimization of the reaction condition parameters, the oxidative coupling system was evaluated for various alcohols with different substituted 2-amino/hydroxy/mercaptoanilines to verify the generality of the oxidative coupling system. Furthermore, the reusability of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was tested. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemical reagents were of analytical grade and purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (SCRC) without further purification. Poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (average Mn ∼ 5800) (Pluronic®P-123), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 12 M), n-butanol (AR), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 28.4 % SiO2), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99 %), Mn(NO3)2 (98 %), n-hexane (99 %), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR), ethanol (AR), o-phenylenediamine (99 %), benzyl alcohol (99 %), 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinooxy (TEMPO, 98 %), ethyl acetate (AR), Celite (36.8 μm), 1,2-diamino-4,5-difluorobenzene (98 %), 4,5-dichloro-o-phenylenediamine (98 %), 1,2-diamino-3-chlorobenzene (98 %), 1,2-diamino-4-bromobenzene (98 %), 4-nitro-o-phenylenediamine (98 %), 4,6-dimethyl-1,2-phenylenediamine (98 %), 3,4-diaminotoluene (98 %), 4-trifluoromethyl-1,2-phenylenediamine (98 %), 4-methoxy-o-phenylenediamine (98 %), 2-aminobenzenethiol (97 %), 2-amino-3-fluorophenol (97 %), 2-amino-4-bromophenol (98 %), 2-fluorobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 3-fluorobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 4-fluorobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol (99 %), 3-chlorobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 2-chlorobenzyl alcohol (99 %), 2-bromobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 4-bromobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 4-methylbenzyl alcohol (99 %), 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol (98 %), 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol (98 %), biphenyl-4-methanol (98 %), m-tolylmethanol (98 %), 3-cyanobenzyl alcohol (98 %), 2-hydroxybenzyl alcohol (98 %), 3-methyl-1-butanol (99 %), (1H-pyrrol-2-yl)methanol (97 %), cinnamyl alcohol (99 %), phenethyl alcohol (99 %), and (1H-indol-3-yl)methanol (98 %). 2.2 Preparation of mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework The mesoporous material KIT-6 was prepared according to the reported literature (see Supporting Information) [43]. 5.28 mmol of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 10.56 mmol of Mn(NO3)2 were dissolved in 6 mL of water as precursor solution. 6.0 g of KIT-6 was dispersed in 400 mL of n-hexane under stirring for 1 h through a magnetic stirrer (Heidolph), and then the precursor solution was added quickly. The mixture was stirred (rotation rate = 500 rpm) constantly for 3 h at 20 °C and the precursor CuMn@KIT-6 was obtained by filtration. Next, the CuMn@KIT-6 was vacuum dried thoroughly for 8 h at 50 °C through a vacuum drying oven (Shanghai Jinghong Experimental Equipment Co., Ltd), and then was calcined at 600 °C in the air for 4 h with a slow ramp of 1 °C min−1 through a muffle furnace (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The obtained powders were removed from the mesoporous silica template KIT-6 thoroughly by reacting with 12 g of NaOH in water. Through filtration and washing with water, the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was obtained. 2.3 Characterization Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was performed using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker) with the Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15418 nm). N2 physisorption isotherms were recorded using a Tristar II 3020 instrument (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation) at 77 K. The specific surface areas were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution curves were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrums were obtained using a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi instrument (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) characterizations were performed using a HITACHI Regulus 8100 instrument (Hitachi) and an Oxford Ultim Max 65 instrument (Oxford), respectively. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was performed using a Hitachi HT-7700 apparatus (Hitachi). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images with the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were obtained by a JEM 2100 apparatus (Japan Electron Optics Laboratory, JEOL). High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) characterization was recorded on an Agilent 1100 Series instrument (Agilent). Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) characterization was performed using a Bruker Avance III 500 MHz instrument (Bruker). High-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) characterization was performed using an Agilent 1290 Infinity instrument (Agilent). 2.4 Catalytic tests General procedure for oxidative coupling reaction of o-phenylenediamine and benzyl alcohol: 0.4 mmol of benzyl alcohol, 0.4 mmol of o-phenylenediamine, and 20 mol% of TEMPO were added into 5 mL of H2O. The 3 mol% of CuMn2O4 was then immersed into the reaction mixture with magnetic stirring for 4 h at 100 °C through a magnetic stirrer (Heidolph). The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature and sufficient ethyl acetate was added to the reaction mixture to fully dissolve the organic substance. Next, the above mixture was filtered through Celite and was eluted with ethyl acetate to remove the catalyst. The target product was obtained by column chromatography and determined by nuclear magnetic resonance. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework The small angle XRD pattern (Fig. S1a) of KIT-6 exhibited four distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ = 0.96°, 1.11°, 1.71°, and 1.83° in the 2 theta range of 0.5–5.0°, corresponding to the (211), (220), (420), and (332) planes, respectively [43,44]. This indicated that the hard template had a highly ordered mesostructure with cubic Ia3d symmetry, which was consistent with the TEM observation results (Figure S1d) [45]. The SEM image (Figure S1e) showed that KIT-6 had an irregular solid appearance [46]. N2 adsorption analysis results (Figure S1b and S1c) indicated that the pore size distribution of KIT-6 was highly uniform, with a specific surface area of 573 m2 g −1 and an average pore diameter of 7 nm [47]. The pore volume was about 0.65 cm3 g−1. The XRD pattern (Fig. 2 a) of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework exhibited clear diffraction peaks at 18.7°, 30.2°, 35.7°, 43.4°, 54.1°, 57.7° and 63.2°, corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511) and (440) planes of the spinel CuMn2O4, respectively (JCPDS: 01–074–2422) [48,49]. No diffraction peak from CuO or Mn2O3 was observed in the final product, suggesting that the precursor was fully converted to spinel CuMn2O4. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework showed a significant increase in nitrogen adsorption at p/p0 higher than 0.5 (Fig. 2b), which corresponded to the mesostructure. According to isotherm calculations based on BET and BJH methods, the mesostructure resulted in a large specific surface area of 47.76 m2 g−1, a pore volume of 0.125 cm3 g−1, and an average pore diameter of 3.745 nm. The chemical state of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was characterized by XPS. The spectra were analyzed using XPSPEAK (Version 4.1) and the background response of the peaks was eliminated using the Shirley algorithm. The binding energies of XPS spectrums were calibrated according to the C 1 s (C–C bonds of the adventitious carbon) at 284.8 eV. The survey spectrum (Fig. 2c) showed the presence of Cu, Mn, and O in the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework. Due to the principle of charge neutrality and the Jahn-Teller effect, Cu and Mn ions with different valence states can coexist in Cu-Mn mixed-metal oxides [29,50,51]. The Cu 2p spectrum showed six peaks in the 925–965 eV range, indicating that the Cu ions were in a complex state. The Cu 2p spectrum (Fig. 2d) showed two sharp and narrow peaks at 930.7 eV and 950.3 eV, which was consistent with the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu+, indicating the presence of Cu+ in the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework [52,53]. Meanwhile, the peaks at 933.6 and 953.4 eV were attributed to the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of the octahedrally coordinated Cu2+ [52,53]. In addition, two strong satellite peaks at 943.4 and 961.7 eV were attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 [53,54]. The binding energies of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 with a spacing of about 20 eV suggested the presence of Cu+ and Cu2+ [53,55]. Similar to Cu ions, Mn ions also exist in different valence states. The Mn 2p spectrum (Fig. 2e) showed two broad main peaks with shoulders at 641.7 and 652.7 eV, corresponding to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively [53,56]. Furthermore, in the high-resolution spectrum of Mn 2p spectrum, two broad main peaks of Mn 2p could be further split into four overlapping peaks. The fitted peaks at 641.7 and 644.5 eV corresponded to Mn3+ and Mn4+ ions, respectively [53,54]. Meanwhile, the fitted peaks at 652.7 and 654.1 eV corresponded to Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively, indicating the presence of Mn4+ and Mn3+ in the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework [53,54]. The O 1 s spectrum showed two peaks with binding energies of 529.4 eV and 530.6 eV, which might be attributed to the formation of the bonds between the metal and the oxygen as well as oxygen adsorption (Fig. 2f) [53,54]. The above results suggested that the Mn and Cu ions were in different valence states in the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework. The SEM and the TEM images (Fig. 3 a and b) indicated that the CuMn2O4 product had a highly ordered mesoporous structure (i.e., a mesostructured framework with long-range mesostructure ordering). In addition, the size of the CuMn2O4 nanoframework was about 7 nm, which was consistent with the mean pore size of the mesoporous material KIT-6. In the HRTEM image (Fig. 3c), well-defined lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.250 nm were observed, which matched the (311) crystal plane of spinel CuMn2O4 [57]. The diffraction rings on the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) crystal planes of the spinel CuMn2O4 could be seen in the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 3d), which was consistent with the XRD analysis [58]. The HRTEM and SAED results indicated that the nanoframework of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 product was composed of pure-phase CuMn2O4 nanocrystalline, as is the case for most mesoporous MMO-type materials synthesized by the nanocasting method. The composition and elemental distribution were investigated by EDS analysis. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mappings (Fig. 3e) showed that the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework consisted of only three elements, Cu, Mn, and O, indicating high purity of the catalyst. The analysis showed that the mapping image of Cu and Mn overlapped with the one of O. These results further indicated that the obtained product was composed of single-phase mixed-metal oxide CuMn2O4. 3.2 Catalytic performance in the oxidative coupling reaction In the following work, the effect of catalytic conditions on the oxidative coupling reaction was investigated with CuMn2O4 as the catalyst and H2O as the solvent. Throughout the nanopore structure, the solvent H2O mainly forms short one-dimensional molecular chains and cross-linked hydrogen bonds at the intersections between the pores [41]. During liquid-phase catalysis, these H2O structures must reorganize to accommodate the formation of reactive surface intermediates, leading to a disproportionate increase in entropy beyond the enthalpy loss associated with the destruction of these confined solvent molecules [41]. The above phenomenon promotes a wide range of catalytic reactions in the nanopores of mesoporous catalysts with H2O as the solvent. The oxidative coupling reaction of o-phenylenediamine (1a) with benzyl alcohol (2a) was chosen as a model reaction to determine the optimized reaction conditions, and the effects of the equivalent ratio of reactants and reaction temperature were first investigated. Reactions with the participation of 10 mol% TEMPO and 3 % CuMn2O4 catalyst with different equivalent ratios of 1a and 2a were performed at a reaction temperature of 80 °C. As shown in Table 1 , entries 1–3, the reaction with an equivalent ratio of 1:1 exhibited the highest yield of 85 %. By increasing the reaction temperature to 100 °C and 120 °C, the yields were significantly increased to 91 % (Table 1, entries 4,5). However, when the temperature was further increased to 140 °C, the yield dropped to 86 % (Table 1, entry 6). With a fixed equivalent ratio of 1:1 and reaction temperature of 100 °C, increasing the reaction time to 4 h was found to further improve the conversion to 94 % (Table 1, entry 7). A further increase of reaction time to 6 h resulted in no significant change (Table 1, entry 8). With the reaction time fixed at 4 h, the effect of the amount of TEMPO was further investigated. Nearly no reaction occurred without the addition of TEMPO, while the yield reached 99 % when the amount of TEMPO was increased to 20 mol% (Table 1, entries 9, 10). Finally, the effect of the amount of catalyst, the CuMn2O4 nanoframework, was investigated. The yield decreased when the amount of catalyst was reduced to 2 mol% (Table 1, entry 11). The blank control experiment showed that, without the catalyst, no reaction occurred in 8 h (Table 1, entry 12). In summary, the optimized condition of the reaction of o-phenylenediamine and benzyl alcohol was 100 °C and 4 h, with 3 mol% of CuMn2O4 as the catalyst and 20 mol% of TEMPO as the base. After obtaining the optimized conditions, the scope of this reaction was further investigated using different o-phenylenediamines (1) and alcohols (2). Overall, both o-phenylenediamines and benzyl alcohols with electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituent groups reacted to produce the corresponding products with yields from 91 % to 99 % (Table 2 ). The fluoro-, chloro-, and bromo-substituted o-phenylenediamine and benzyl alcohols were efficiently converted to the corresponding products in yields higher than 91 % (Table 2, entries 1–13), irrespective of whether the substituents were ortho, meta, or para. In addition, high conversions were achieved for o-phenylenediamine with strong electron-withdrawing groups (such as -NO2 and -CF3) or benzyl alcohol with strong electron-withdrawing groups (-CN), with yields of 96 %, 92 %, and 93 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 14–16). It is noteworthy that o-phenylenediamine and benzyl alcohols with electron-donating groups (such as -CH3, -OCH3, and -OH) also reacted in high yields (> 92 %), with the position of the substituent group on the benzene ring having no significant effect on the reaction (Table 2, entries 17–23). Moreover, it was also observed that the presence of the phenyl group as substituent group on benzyl alcohol did not limit the formation of the corresponding product (Table 2, entry 24). Both o-phenylenediamine and benzyl alcohol with substituent groups were further tested under the optimized conditions and the corresponding products were obtained in yields higher than 92 % (Table 2, entries 25–31). When using 2-hydroxy/mercaptoanilines instead of o-phenylenediamine as the reactant, the corresponding products were also successfully synthesized under the optimized conditions with yields > 98 % (Table 2, entries 32–34). Furthermore, the possibility of oxidative coupling reactions of o-phenylenediamine with heterocyclic alcohols or aliphatic alcohols was explored under the optimized reaction conditions. We were pleased to find that these reactions showed yields > 93 % in obtaining the corresponding products (Table 2, entries 35–39). The above results indicated that the synthesized mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was suitable for the oxidative coupling of aromatic, heterocyclic, and aliphatic alcohols with o-phenylenediamine. The isolated yields and mass of these reactions were calculated and listed in Scheme S1, and the molecular structures of all products were also analyzed by NMR and HRMS (see ESI). The results demonstrated that the oxidative coupling catalyzed by mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was tolerant to functional groups and has high yields, which makes it a practical method for the synthesis of benzimidazole derivatives. 3.3 Reaction mechanism Typically, in the spinel-phase MMO AB2O4, the cations A and B have charges of +2 and +3, respectively, and occupy tetrahedral and octahedral sites in the cubic close-packed lattice, respectively. However, it is only a simplified ideal model. It has been reported in the literature that, in MMO AB2O4, A and B ions occupy tetrahedral sites in a 1:1 ratio, and A and B ions occupy octahedral sites in a 1:3 ratio [59]. This complex coordination state leads to disproportionation of A and B ions so that Cu+, Cu2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ ions appear simultaneously in the XPS characterization. Meanwhile, the synergistic effect between the above ions in the spinel-phase crystals may be the reason for the high activity of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework. In addition, this oxidative coupling system uses O2 from the air as the final oxygen source, and a small amount of TEMPO is a key co-catalyst for the selective oxidation system, regenerated continuously during the redox cycle [60]. The TEMPO is low dosage and recyclable in this system, which is in line with the concept of green chemistry. The mesostructure and large specific surface area facilitate the exposure of catalytic active sites, which improves the activity of the catalyst. Under the synergistic catalysis of TEMPO and mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework, the alcohol is selectively oxidized to generate an aldehyde, which is then further oxidatively coupled with 2-amino/hydroxy/mercaptoaniline to obtain a benzimidazole derivative (Fig. S2) [61]. 3.4 Recovery and reuse of the catalyst After reaction, the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was easily separated and recovered by filtration, which was a major advantage of heterogeneous catalysts. After washing with ethanol and distilled water, the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework could be directly reused in subsequent cycles, and no copper or manganese was detected in the target products. Our results indicated that the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework had high stability and could be reused for at least five cycles with negligible activity decay (Fig. 4 ). After the cycling test, the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework was characterized by XRD and TEM to further verify its stability. The XRD pattern (Figure S3a) shows the diffraction peaks assigned to the crystal planes of the spinel CuMn2O4 (JCPDS: 01–074–2422), which are almost the same as the diffraction peaks detected before the reaction. The TEM image (Figure S3b) still shows the mesostructured framework. The above results further illustrate the excellent stability of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework. Taking the oxidative coupling reaction of o-phenylenediamine (1a) and benzyl alcohol (2a) as an example, we further compared the catalytic performance of mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework with other catalysts reported in the literature (Table 3 ) [62–69]. The comparison results showed that the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework developed in this work catalyzed the reaction in the highest yield. In addition, it required the lowest reaction temperature, the shortest reaction times, and less amount of catalysts than most of the other catalysts. Furthermore, its 1:1 molar ratio of 1a and 2a showed the highest atom economy (mass of desired products/total mass of reactants). The use of water as the solvent was also more environmentally friendly compared to the organic solvents used in other studies. 4 Conclusions A mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework, created by a nanocasting strategy in the mesoporous material KIT-6 hard template, was applied to synthesize benzimidazole derivatives through air oxidative coupling in water. The characterizations of mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework demonstrate that its stable framework structure and large specific surface area ensure its stable high activity and cyclic performance. The solvent reorganization and the Jahn-Teller effect further promote the catalytic activity of the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework, which leads to its excellent catalytic performance in the oxidative coupling of various alcohols with 2-amino/hydroxy/mercaptoanilines. What's more, the reaction system is mild in nature, using water as solvent and air as oxidant, which is in line with the concept of green chemistry. All these results demonstrate that the mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework is an efficient heterogeneous oxidative coupling catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Mixed-metal oxide (MMO) CuMn2O4 nanoframework with a mesoporous structure was synthesized. The advantages of this mesoporous MMO are its large specific surface area, uniform pore size, and various metal valence states. MMO CuMn2O4 nanoframework showed efficient catalytic activity in the oxidative coupling of 2-amino/hydroxy/mercaptoanilines with various alcohols in the preparation of benzimidazoles, benzoxazoles, and benzothiazoles using water as the sole solvent in high yields. The efficient catalytic activity is mainly attributed to large specific surface area, increased number of active sites, solvent reorganization between the pores of mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework, and the various electronic states of the copper and manganese ions (Cu+, Cu2+, Mn3+, Mn4+) due to the Jahn-Teller effect. This research provides new insights into improving the catalytic performance of catalyst for the synthesis of nitrogen-containing five-membered ring compounds.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous CuMn2O4 nanoframework as an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of benzimidazole derivatives through air oxidative coupling in water
